title: Policies of noise emissions and of rolling resistance presentation

author: Fabienne Anfosso - Lédée, LCPC - Laboratoire Central des Ponts et Chaussées

segmentation: Ladies and gentlemen.

It's not the problem of the road users, but it's more the problem of residents near the road.
But anyhow, it has to be taken into account.
As a side effect of the road.
For this purpose there has been some legal requirements or legislation that has been.
Derive the by the easy.
For instance with Easy Directive 2249 that.
That make that require that all big cities and big transportation infrastructure draw their noise mapping.
That is to to predict the noise level around infrastructure on all around it.
And from this Maps to derive some action plans to reduce the noise.

So in this respect there is some requirements existing, some legislation existing, but in fact it takes into account global noise in the environment, that is noise emission from the road or for any other transportation source.
But it also includes some propagation.
So it means it in implies a lot of parameters that are taken into account, not only noise emission, so that what makes it.
Ficlet.

But in this national regulations.
Sometimes they are using different noise indicators from one country to another.
They are using different legal thresholds.
That makes it quite complicated on also different application schemes in some countries, for instance, you just need to calculate predict the the sound levels.
You don't need to check it whether in other countries then you have to check it by measurements.
So this is different in application system of this legal require.
Now going to the noise emission part.
What we can say on a scientific point of view, Rd noise emission mainly is mainly due to the tie rod interaction.
That's a fact we know.
So with this respect then we have to derive some technical tools to do something about that.
On a technical point of view, there are different tools that are existing to reduce Rd noise emission.
So we can improve the vehicle tire conception.
We can improve or we can apply some traffic management systems like require some speed limits or trying to reduce the traffic volume by rerouting some part of the traffic.
Or we can increase the fluidity.
That's another tool.
We can also improve the road surface conception and that's what we are mainly dealing in inteiro safe problem.
Or we can also build noise barriers.
That's the technical tools that are available for Rd engineers.
But what, how is it translated in terms of?
Legislation, well in terms of legislation here you have the general problem noise problem in the environment.
Then there are some requirements that are existing on vehicle noise emission.
There are some requirements existing on tire noise emission and you probably heard recently from the Directive 2143 from EC that is being under review.
There are also existing standards for for the assessment of noise.
Very poor performances.
In the EN 1793 series of standards.
But no requirements really exist for Rd noise performance, there's a lack of.
Legal requirements or.
Technical requirements standards for this actor of.
Problem.
On the point of view of the road authority.
We we know from several groups that exist in Europe.
That there is probably need considered by Rd authority and this need can be summarizing to be questions.
One of the first question is how to promote the use of low noise surface in the country or.
In European countries.
So how to make the incentive of using Lonos Rd Surface two?
I bet noise emission at the source.
And the second question is, what is really a low noise surface?
We need for that indicator level of performance to be defined an probably a common one would be a good thing from the point of your Rd authority.
That's what we heard at the moment from the road owner or Rd engineer POV.
His problem would be which Flowserve noise surface, low noise Rd surface to choose when designing a Rd project.
We are definitely probably lacking.
Kind of labeling of Rd surface in terms of noise, performance labeling or classification system.
And also how to specify intended documents, how to specify the required performance and for that we have to rely on measurement method.
To be able to check it.
So how to check it and which method to use?

Maybe you know that there are several available methods for measuring for assessing noise performance of Rd surface is you've probably heard about pass by noise measurement, SPB, oh, or close proximity noise measurement CPX.
These methods are not equivalent.
They do not give the same levels.
So which one is better adapted?
And from the road contractor POV, his question is well, as I guess how to promote the use of my lonos product and my country and probably outside in my country.
So there are the questions we're asking and that maybe we are expecting some feedback from from you.

Who is going to talk about the all the third parameter to we're considering that is rolling resistance.

I am from the Federal Highway Research Institute bust in Germany.

A short overview over the influence of all the.
The influence of the road surface on rolling resistance and we performed literature survey.
And I can show the results of this.
When you're driving on the road.
You have.
You're faced with many resistances.
First of all, there is the aerodynamic resistance.
The climbing resistance.
And the resistance of acceleration.
Which has.
Nothing to do with the resistance of the tire and the wheel.
The resistance of the tire and wheel can be.
The flexing resistance of the sidewalls of the tire while driving over the road.
Then the deflection of the pavement.
Which is something we have to deal with as long as we are from the from the roadside.
Damping of the unevenness which leads to heating up of the dampers.
The bearing friction, aerodynamic resistance of the wheel itself.
An friction and attention.
The highlighted parts are that ones that come from from the roadside.
On this diagram on the X axis you can see the velocity in kilometers per hour and on the epsilon axis the percentage.
Of the rolling resistance as part of the of the total energy loss.
You can see.
That when you're driving at a constant speed of approximately 50 kilometers per hour.
Your spending or the rolling resistance needs approximately 50% of the whole.
Energy to overcome the resistance is the driving resistances.
At 100 kilometers per hour.
No, I was wrong, sorry.
Driving in urban area, which means 5050 kilometers per hour.
The rolling resistance needs approximately 775 percentage of the total energy consumption and at 100 KPH we are at 50%.
Overall, you can say that every 4th filling of the tank.
Is a result of the rolling resistance of your tires, which means approximately 25 percentage percent of the total energy consumption due to the rolling resistance.

There might be some.
Interest in.
Optimizing the roads.
At.
The rolling resistance.

It has something to do with the characteristics with the texture of the road.
Surface that has an influence on the rolling resistance.
There are.
The unevenness the megatexture, them architecture and the microtexture as you know.
And the main question we're faced with is what influences the roads.
Surface is rolling resistance at the most.
Which part of this?
Four texture characteristics have to be improved.
To decrease the rolling resistance.
I'm since we have no policy at in Europe.
Actually, today we had to perform a literature survey of measurement results to get an answer to this question.
How can we optimize the road?
The results of this literature survey were.
A little bit confusing.
Because the results.
Show different.
Different characters of the of the road that that influenced the rolling resistance at the most.
Altogether they have, they say that increasing rolling resistance results in increasing fuel consumption and CO2 emission, which is quite logical.
Um?
Another common thing is that a rolling resistance increases marginal, but almost linear with velocity.
And.
That the rolling resistance has marginal influence on fuel consumption while driving with an uneven pattern means.
The rolling resistance is not that important.
While driving at urban traffic with many stop and go phases.
Just an example of some some literature.
Studies we've made there was a research of VTi.
The influence of Marco a macro and megatexture on fuel consumptions.
These tests have been performed with with the passenger car in 20 different Rd surfaces have been tested.
And the result of this.

Investigation was that the unevenness which in this case means a wavelength between 0.6, three and two 3.15 meters, influences the rolling resistance the most, and the influence of the microtexture increases with velocity.
Another research of VTi together with UG.
They performed tests of 100 different passenger car tires on the laboratory, Tom.
Or on the test track.
They performed the rolling resistance tests on the laboratory term of TOG and the noise and schedule resistance measurements took place at the test track.
And the noise was measured via VTi CPX method.
It is unknown if the texture was measured as well.
There was a low correlation between rolling resistance and rolling noise.
And as well, a low correlation between Skitter assistance and rolling noise with which I think is.
Very important, because if this if that is true there is there would be no conflict of goals.
In optimizing the road in with schedule assistance and rolling noise and rolling resistance.
As well.
As you can see, performed research.
Also with actual vehicles on French highways.
And on a test drive, can you not?
The result of this.
Research was that the influence of the unevenness and the influence of Microtexture may combine, but the influences are not linear.
And the evilness is.
As important is microtexture.
And they are both influencing the fuel consumption.
But another result was that the driving habits and their own alignment.
May have a bigger influence on fuel consumption.
CO2 emission.
Then a positive had research.
I'm.
We measured 12 different services with four different tires.
There was a correlation between rolling resistance and noise.
Emission was not detectable.
And best correlation between rolling noise and texture was found at the micro texture range.
Which is another.
Result of investigation.
And the megatexture at this test had the lowest correlation.
You see, the problem here is we have many different investigations.
And most of them have different results, and until now we don't know which one of the of the road characteristics are influencing.
The rolling resistance at the most and where is the screw we have to.
To turn to improve the rolling resistance of the pavements.
There was another research.
This main part is that it showed that about 40% difference from minimal to maximum value of the rolling resistance could be measured.
So there must be an influence of the of the road texture on the rolling resistance.
And again, no.
Between no correlation between low noise pavement and rolling resistance.
Be detected.
So my conclusion is.
That the road surface characteristics have an influence, as I said.
It's not sure which one of the characteristics.
Is influencing the most and until now we are not.
We cannot say that there must be a conflict of good script resistance, low rolling noise and low rolling resistance.
So I hope you can read this is the list of my references and I come to the end of my presentation.
Thank you for your attention.
